title: Diploma in Design Thinking
headline: Learn more about design thinking and powerful modern design tools with this free online design course.
description: This free online design thinking course will teach you the best process for creating and testing a new idea, or improving a product or service. Everyone has at some point encountered a problem with a product or service that didn't need to be there, and we'd often like to have a strong word with those who designed the solution. We can't fix the terrible designs of the past, but Design Thinking can teach you how to design better in the future!

courseDescription:
This free online design thinking course will introduce you to people-centered design and problem discovery. You will learn about the seven mindsets for designers, how there is more to design than aesthetics, and the perceived value that people place on what they see. Next, you will learn how to examine and reflect on design problems. You will also study design research, design analysis, and how to generate ideas that will take the world by storm.

You will then learn how to create storyboards to visualize your concept and to help you with your design process. You will also learn about prototyping and how it can help your design development. You will then study usability testing, how and with whom it should be carried out, and how to debrief and record your results. Finally, you will learn about the design rationale and how to create a great pitch for your design.

Innovative products make our lives easier and save us a lot of time. This free online design thinking course will be very useful to professionals who are working, or want to work, in the areas of product and service design, and will guide them through the main techniques and methodologies that designers use during the design process. So why wait? Start the course today, and in a few short hours you'll have gained a fantastic new skill and set of knowledge!

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will be introduced to design thinking for people centered design. You will learn about how to think for designing. You will learn about the 7 mindsets for designers. You will learn about been people centered with your designs. You will learn about how there is more than aesthetics to design. You will learn about perceived value that people place on what they see. You will learn about the paths for people centered design.
topics: The Need to be people Centered

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will be introduced to examining and reflecting on design problems. You will learn about questions you should ask about your problem. You will learn about framing your problem from a design point of view.
topics: Examine and Reflect on the Problem
Reconsider the Right Problem to Solve

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will be introduced to research for design. You will learn about questions you should consider when designing. You will learn about framing questions for interviewing. You will learn about a userâ€™s mental model and what it is.
topics: Research with Users and Their Contexts - Part I
Research with Users and Their Contexts - Part II

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn about seeing themes from user stories and about a customer journey map. You will learn about what a persona is, what it represents and why to create one. You will learn about scenarios and how they complement personas. You will learn about insight statements and what a design strategy statement is.

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Design Thinking - First Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Design Thinking - First Assessment

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn about methods for innovating products from ideas. You will also learn about bundling your ideas together and creating a concept.
topics: Bundle Ideas and Create a Concept

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will be introduced to the storytelling approach to design. You will learn about creating storyboards to visualize your concept and how storyboards can help you with your design process. You will learn about prototyping what it is and how it helps your design development.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will be introduced to usability testing and why you should have users evaluate your design. You will learn about what design freedom is and who should evaluate your design.
topics: Introduction to Usability Testing - Learning Outcomes
Introduction to Usability Testing - Lesson Summary

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module you will learn about refining and pitching your design. You will learn about prototype fidelity and how it changes as the design progresses. You will learn about pitching your design and what a design rational is.
topics: Record Results, Enhance, Retest and Refine Design
Create a Pitch for your Design

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Diploma in Design Thinking - Second Assessment
modules.description: You must score 80% or more to pass this assessment.
topics: Diploma in Design Thinking - Second Assessment

modules.name: Module
topics: Diploma in Design thinking - Final Assessment

• People Centered Design Methodology

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• People Centered Design Methodology

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • Design thinking is thinking for creative problem solving using tools and techniques of innovation.

    Design thinking requires you to:
    • Empathize and understand what the user needs.
    • Think out of the box to ideate and then arrive at a solution to meet that need.
    • Make, refine, make, refine.
    • Collaborate in a diverse team.
  • People centered design is not about how a product works on the inside or looks on the outside, it's about how the product behaves and is used in the real world.

    Design is more than the aesthetics and artifacts associated with products, its a strategic function that focuses on what people want, need and dream of.

• Examine and Reflect on the Problem

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Examine and Reflect on the Problem

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Reconsider the right problem to solve

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Reconsider the right problem to solve

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • To reflect the problem, you ask three main questions:
    1. What do we know about the problem?
    2. What questions do we have about it?
    3. How could we be thinking about it?

    With examining your problem, you need to ask, what is the real problem. Look at different angles, break the problem down, rephrase the problem e.g. "design a vase" to "design a container for flowers".

    To reconsider the problem to solve you to explore the design challenge and put a frame around the reconsidered problem, to reconsider for the 'right' problem to solve.

    When asked to solve a problem ask WHY to explore the problem, and you need to ask why to your answers after you have explored your problem.

    Framing you design problem means you:
    1. Articulate the problem you are trying to solve.
    2. Consider impact, early solutions and constraints.
    3. Rephrase the problem.

• Question Framing and Conducting Research

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Question Framing and Conducting Research

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • When designing, you need to consider:
    1. Who are the people for whom we are designing?
    2. What is their context of use of this product/service?
    3. What are they currently using/doing in this context?
    4. What are some expressed and unexpressed needs?

    In research for design you:
    â€¢ Understand needs and characteristics.
    â€¢ Want to know what to do next.
    â€¢ Must inform the design we are working on.

    The main difference between market research and design research is, in market research you are asking "how many" and in design research you are asking "why".

    For framing questions and interviewing, you should: set proper expectations, listen, minimize biased questions, be friendly, avoid generalizations, and don't forget the non-verbal cues.

    Again, as before ask "Why" about everything even some of the answers you get.

    When doing user research, you are trying to uncover the mental models of the target audience and understand their language and values.

    A mental model is a person's thought process for how something works.

• Insight Statements, Design Strategy Statement

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• Insight Statements, Design Strategy Statement

  • Select your Video URL in the Edit Panel

• The key points from this module are:
  • The theme you see amidst all the user stories you hear, is the Analysis for Design.

    A customer journey map is a visual aid to display the customer's journey buying/using your product/service.

    A persona is not a specific individual from a targeted group, but a representative of a group of people. A persona encompasses the most important and relevant features common to that group and relevant to this design.

    Personas are fictional characters drawn from user research, that serve as example cases during development.

    A scenario articulates the background and setting around the usage of the product/service you are creating. Scenarios complement personas.

    Insights are your discoveries form your research that will serve as triggers for design ideation.

    "How might we" questions are important as they answer how you might solve your problem. You will reframe your key insight statements as "How might we" questions to turn those challenges into opportunities for design.

    The design strategy statement is where in one sentence you try to describe what your project is.
